thread.title: Students with disabilities belong in integrated classrooms
thread.title_full: Students with disabilities belong in integrated classrooms - The Washington Post

author: John Woodrow Cox
title: Students with disabilities belong in integrated classrooms
text:
(Monkey Business Images/iStock) October 18 at 7:47 PM When I read Jay Mathews’s Oct. 12 Education column, “ How can a special-education student fail ﬁnals yet still pass? Sadly, it’s easy ,” I had to check the date of the paper to be sure it wasn’t left over from the 20th century. Mr. Mathews’s support for “self-contained classes” — school-system-speak for segregation — for placement of a student with a disability ignored that special education is a service, not a place. Modern practice uses “ natural supports ” to help people with disabilities.
Mr. Mathews disregarded the years of effort at integration and inclusion of students with disabilities and perpetuated the archaic but still prevalent attitude that out-of-sight-out-of-mind is the best way to deal with people with disabilities.
Also, the lack of people-first language (“disabled student” instead of “student with a disability”) defines people by their disability.
Mike McLaughlin , Laurel
